------=_NextPart_000_028D_01CB2757.C7BA6270
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Colin,
 
Could you elaborate on your conceptualization of "micro-mutations"? I'd hate
to use my heuristics ...
 
Ken Lloyd

  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Monday, July 19, 2010 3:16 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Node-split mutation


  

On 19 July 2010 07:41, Ken <kstanley@...
<mailto:kstanley%40cs.utexas.edu> > wrote:
>
> Another interesting type of node split might be a parallel split rather
than the serial split you
> described. So you would basically duplicate the node and its incoming and
outgoing connections.
> That might be sort of like gene duplication that can then lead to a
divergence. However, the new
> weights would perhaps need to be calibrated since it would double the
power of the prior
> single-node output.

Interesting. Alternatively you could divide up the existing
connections between the two nodes - but that would likely break the
functionality of the existing structure. You could copy a subset if
the connections to the new node, but that likely just creates some
broken functionaloty again; best copy the whole thing and micro-mutate
from there.

I'm thinking the output connection weights could be either initialised
to zero, or drastically reduced (divide by some largish number). Or we
could skip copying the output connections altogether (maybe just one
chosen randomly for starters) and allow micro-mutations to connect up
the new node's output side.

Colin.
